children.subject:
I think because CS 189 is so popular, you'll likely have a hard time getting in as a non-major, and I wouldn't necessarily count on being able to take it (but you never know). I'd have a backup option that you like in mind! I wasn't a CS major and I was able to get into CS 188 and CS 164, so while the popularity of those classes fluctuates semester to semester I think you can probably get in.

Since you're not a CS major, I'd see if any of the more mathematical EE(CS) classes interest you -- e.g. EECS 126 and 127. CS/EECS majors don't get any priority signing up for those classes, so you have the same chances of getting in as everyone else, and I'm sure the Applied Math advisors would count them towards a CS cluster (the impression I got when they were approving my potential clusters was that they're pretty loose with what they'll accept for a cluster).

i think with the introduction of Data 102 (the data science major's machine learning class) this past semester, the demand for CS 189 will drop a lot. So maybe you'll have a good chance of getting in.

history.content:
Hi Guys,

           How hard is it to get into cs upper divs  as a applied math major , as I have to take 3 upper div classes of cs to form a cs cluster for applied math. I am planning to take cs189 ,cs188 and cs164.

                                                  Thank you!
history.subject: Getting into cs upper divs as a applied math major
